unredacted: The RPD referenced objective evidence that the shilling is the currency used in Somalia. The RPD found that the Appellant would know the currency used in Somalia if the only form of payment he received was cash, which undermined his credibility. The RPD concluded that it was unlikely that the Appellant worked at the club in Kismayo, which brings into question if he lived in Somalia.
redacted: The RPD referenced objective evidence that the shilling is the currency used in Somalia. The RPD found that the Appellant would know the currency used in Somalia if the only form of payment he received was cash, which undermined his credibility. The RPD concluded that it was unlikely that the Appellant worked at the club in Kismayo, which brings into question if he lived in Somalia.

unredacted: The Appellant argues that in Somalia they call the money “Somali lacag" (direct tanslation: Somali money), which is what the Appellant testified to at the hearing. The Appellant argues that the RPD did not ask the Appellant what the currency was in Somalia and, if asked, the Appellant would have said it was the shilling. “Civilians in Somalia simply refer to money as ‘Somali money’ they don't specify the currency. The interpreter also directly interpreted what the Appellant stated, so it was interpreted as Somali money. The Appellant submits that according to the dictionary, ‘lacag’ means money, currency, cash. Hence, the Appellant's testimony was not wrong.” The Appellant does not reference any objective evidence to support his argument.
redacted: The Appellant argues that in Somalia they call the money “Somali lacag" (direct tanslation: Somali money), which is what the Appellant testified to at the hearing. The Appellant argues that the RPD did not ask the Appellant what the currency was in Somalia and, if asked, the Appellant would have said it was the shilling. “Civilians in Somalia simply refer to money as ‘Somali money’ they don't specify the currency. The interpreter also directly interpreted what the Appellant stated, so it was interpreted as Somali money. The Appellant submits that according to the dictionary, ‘lacag’ means money, currency, cash. Hence, the Appellant's testimony was not wrong.” The Appellant does not reference any objective evidence to support his argument.

unredacted: I have reviewed both the transcript and the audio recording of the hearing. The RPD clearly asked him to identify the Somali money he was given and specifically asked what it was called. Following my review of the audio recording, I find that the Appellant answered the question differently when he replied “Somali dollar” than when he replied “Somali money.” It is also clear from both the recording and the transcript that the interpretation of the answers was different.
redacted: I have reviewed both the transcript and the audio recording of the hearing. The RPD clearly asked him to identify the Somali money he was given and specifically asked what it was called. Following my review of the audio recording, I find that the Appellant answered the question differently when he replied “Somali dollar” than when he replied “Somali money.” It is also clear from both the recording and the transcript that the interpretation of the answers was different.

unredacted: I find that the RPD did not err when it found that the Appellant did not correctly identify the currency of Somalia and that this undermined the credibility of his claim that he worked in a market and lived in Somalia.
redacted: I find that the RPD did not err when it found that the Appellant did not correctly identify the currency of Somalia and that this undermined the credibility of his claim that he worked in a market and lived in Somalia.

unredacted: When the Appellant’s counsel asked him about the location of his clan in Somalia, the Appellant replied, “Adal.” His counsel asked if his clan could be found in other parts of Somalia, to which he replied, “…there are a few in many other areas [b]ut most of them are in Mogadishu city.” Appellant’s counsel also asked if there were any in Kismayo and the Appellant replied no and that he did not meet any members of his clan in Kismayo.
redacted: When the Appellant’s counsel asked him about the location of his clan in Somalia, the Appellant replied, “Adal.” His counsel asked if his clan could be found in other parts of Somalia, to which he replied, “…there are a few in many other areas [b]ut most of them are in Mogadishu city.” Appellant’s counsel also asked if there were any in Kismayo and the Appellant replied no and that he did not meet any members of his clan in Kismayo.

unredacted: The RPD cited objective evidence that the Dir clan are scattered in small villages in the southeastearn region of Somalia and Kismayo; that the Somali clan system shapes the social, political and economic life; and that clan affiliation is the main identity factor within the Somali nation.
redacted: The RPD cited objective evidence that the Dir clan are scattered in small villages in the southeastearn region of Somalia and Kismayo; that the Somali clan system shapes the social, political and economic life; and that clan affiliation is the main identity factor within the Somali nation.

unredacted: Given the importance of clan affiliation in Somalia, the RPD made a negative credibility finding because the Appellant could not provide more details about his own clan and that he did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, that he is a member of the Dir clan.
redacted: Given the importance of clan affiliation in Somalia, the RPD made a negative credibility finding because the Appellant could not provide more details about his own clan and that he did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, that he is a member of the Dir clan.

unredacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD did not take into account that clan lineage is patrilineal and because the Appellant’s father died when he was young, he did not learn about his claim, nor did it take into account that the Appellant left Somalia when he was only 18 years old. The Appellant also argues that the RPD did not take into account an affidavit from his co-worker Abshir Ibrahim Masood in Kenya confirming the Appellant’s identity and clan identity.
redacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD did not take into account that clan lineage is patrilineal and because the Appellant’s father died when he was young, he did not learn about his claim, nor did it take into account that the Appellant left Somalia when he was only 18 years old. The Appellant also argues that the RPD did not take into account an affidavit from his co-worker Abshir Ibrahim Masood in Kenya confirming the Appellant’s identity and clan identity.

unredacted: While the Somalian Embassy letter does confirm the Appellant’s clan membership it does not detail how it reached its conclusion. I find that the Somalian Embassy confirmation of the Appellant’s clan membership does not carry much weight in light of the Appellant’s very limited knowledge about his clan. I note that the evidence from his co-worker about the Appellant’s clan membership is based on “what my mother narrated to me” without any explanation as to why his mother would be a reliable source of information.
redacted: While the Somalian Embassy letter does confirm the Appellant’s clan membership it does not detail how it reached its conclusion. I find that the Somalian Embassy confirmation of the Appellant’s clan membership does not carry much weight in light of the Appellant’s very limited knowledge about his clan. I note that the evidence from his co-worker about the Appellant’s clan membership is based on “what my mother narrated to me” without any explanation as to why his mother would be a reliable source of information.

unredacted: I have considered the Appellant’s arguments but given his sparse testimony reflecting little knowledge of his clan, that he did not connect with clan members in Kismayo and the objective evidence about the importance of clan identity in Somalia, I agree with the RPD that the Appellant did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, that he is a member of the Dir clan.
redacted: I have considered the Appellant’s arguments but given his sparse testimony reflecting little knowledge of his clan, that he did not connect with clan members in Kismayo and the objective evidence about the importance of clan identity in Somalia, I agree with the RPD that the Appellant did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, that he is a member of the Dir clan.

unredacted: Supporting documents
redacted: Supporting documents

unredacted: The RPD addressed each of the corroborative documents presented by the Appellant. The RPD found that the affidavit from the Appellant’s co-worker and the letter from his mother and a person who hosted him in 2011 did not establish the Appellant’s identity. Given the availability of fraudulent documents in Somalia and the Appellant’s admitted use of a fraudulent passport and study permit application, the RPD was not persuaded by the credibility of the supporting documents.
redacted: The RPD addressed each of the corroborative documents presented by the Appellant. The RPD found that the affidavit from the Appellant’s co-worker and the letter from his mother and a person who hosted him in 2011 did not establish the Appellant’s identity. Given the availability of fraudulent documents in Somalia and the Appellant’s admitted use of a fraudulent passport and study permit application, the RPD was not persuaded by the credibility of the supporting documents.

unredacted: I note that this finding is bolstered by Minister’s evidence that the Appellant failed to present to the RPD a primary identity document in his possession, a Kenyan driving licence, and the Appellant’s admission that he “did not submit this document to the RPD because it is an improperly obtained document which does not establish [his] identity.”
redacted: I note that this finding is bolstered by Minister’s evidence that the Appellant failed to present to the RPD a primary identity document in his possession, a Kenyan driving licence, and the Appellant’s admission that he “did not submit this document to the RPD because it is an improperly obtained document which does not establish [his] identity.”

unredacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD is suggesting that the supporting documents are fraudulent but there is nothing on the face of the documents to suggest that they are fraudulent. I disagree. I have undertaken my own review and note credibility issues on the face of the documents.
redacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD is suggesting that the supporting documents are fraudulent but there is nothing on the face of the documents to suggest that they are fraudulent. I disagree. I have undertaken my own review and note credibility issues on the face of the documents.

unredacted: The co-worker contradicts his evidence in the first paragraph of his affidavit where he states that he is a Kenyan citizen and that his status is that of a permanent resident. There are no dates referenced in the affidavit, and his unnamed mother is identified as the source of much of his information. I agree with the RPD that the co-worker’s affidavit does not credibly establish the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.
redacted: The co-worker contradicts his evidence in the first paragraph of his affidavit where he states that he is a Kenyan citizen and that his status is that of a permanent resident. There are no dates referenced in the affidavit, and his unnamed mother is identified as the source of much of his information. I agree with the RPD that the co-worker’s affidavit does not credibly establish the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.

unredacted: The credibility of affidavit of the Appellant’s mother is adversely affected by the inconsistent evidence on the record about her name:
redacted: The credibility of affidavit of the Appellant’s mother is adversely affected by the inconsistent evidence on the record about her name:

unredacted: As the Appellant’s mother did not provide any confirmation of her identity, I find, on a balance of probabilities, that her letter is not authentic and cannot, therefore, credibly establish the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.
redacted: As the Appellant’s mother did not provide any confirmation of her identity, I find, on a balance of probabilities, that her letter is not authentic and cannot, therefore, credibly establish the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.

unredacted: There is insufficient information in the letter or about the identity of the author who hosted the Appellant in 2011 to assess its credibility. On its face it does not address the determinative issues of the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.
redacted: There is insufficient information in the letter or about the identity of the author who hosted the Appellant in 2011 to assess its credibility. On its face it does not address the determinative issues of the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.

redacted: CONCLUSION

unredacted: For all these reasons, I find that the Appellant has not met his burden to establish, on a balance of probabilities, his personal identity and his identity as a citizen of Somalia.
redacted: For all these reasons, I find that the Appellant has not met his burden to establish, on a balance of probabilities, his personal identity and his identity as a citizen of Somalia.

unredacted: REASONS FOR DECISION

unredacted: OVERVIEW
redacted: OVERVIEW

unredacted: The Appellant Omar Elmi Dihoud claims to be a citizen of Somalia who fears Al-Shabaab as a member of the minority Dir clan. The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) found that the Appellant failed to establish his identity.
redacted: The Appellant Omar Elmi Dihoud claims to be a citizen of Somalia who fears Al-Shabaab as a member of the minority Dir clan. The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) found that the Appellant failed to establish his identity.

unredacted: The Appellant submits that the RPD erred in finding that the Appellant did not establish his identity and in its assessment of his prospective risk in Somalia.
redacted: The Appellant submits that the RPD erred in finding that the Appellant did not establish his identity and in its assessment of his prospective risk in Somalia.

unredacted: The Minister of Citizenship and Immigration (Minister) intervened and presented submissions and documents pursuant to section 110(3) of the IRPA. The Appellant presented reply submissions and an affidavit.
redacted: The Minister of Citizenship and Immigration (Minister) intervened and presented submissions and documents pursuant to section 110(3) of the IRPA. The Appellant presented reply submissions and an affidavit.

unredacted: Following my independent assessment, I find that the RPD did not err when it found that the Appellant failed to establish his identity.
redacted: Following my independent assessment, I find that the RPD did not err when it found that the Appellant failed to establish his identity.

unredacted: DECISION
redacted: DECISION

unredacted: I dismiss the appeal. The RPD was correct in finding that the Appellant is neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection.

unredacted: SCOPE OF THE RAD REVIEW
redacted: SCOPE OF THE RAD REVIEW

unredacted: The Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) reviews decisions of the RPD on a standard of correctness after conducting an independent assessment of the evidence before it. The exception to this rule is where the RPD enjoys a meaningful advantage in assessing and weighing the oral testimony heard, which in particular cases attracts a standard of review of reasonableness adapted to the RAD. Unless specifically stated below, I have applied the correctness standard.
redacted: The Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) reviews decisions of the RPD on a standard of correctness after conducting an independent assessment of the evidence before it. The exception to this rule is where the RPD enjoys a meaningful advantage in assessing and weighing the oral testimony heard, which in particular cases attracts a standard of review of reasonableness adapted to the RAD. Unless specifically stated below, I have applied the correctness standard.

unredacted: ANALYSIS
redacted: ANALYSIS

unredacted: The RPD identified the determinative issue as identity and credibility and found that the Appellant failed to establish his identity on a balance of probabilities.
redacted: The RPD identified the determinative issue as identity and credibility and found that the Appellant failed to establish his identity on a balance of probabilities.

unredacted: The Appellant did not submit any primary identification documents to support his Somali identity. The RPD considered the testimony of the Appellant and his witness, an identity letter from Omar Elmi Dihoud and letters from his co-worker at a Cadaani in Nairobi, his mother and a paternal relative. The RPD referenced objective evidence about the difficulty obtaining primary identification documents and the prevalence of document fraud in Somalia. The RPD also took account of the Kenyan identity used by the Appellant to obtain a passport and to submit an application for a study permit, all of which the Appellant alleges are fraudulent.
redacted: The Appellant did not submit any primary identification documents to support his Somali identity. The RPD considered the testimony of the Appellant and his witness, an identity letter from Omar Elmi Dihoud and letters from his co-worker at a Cadaani in Nairobi, his mother and a paternal relative. The RPD referenced objective evidence about the difficulty obtaining primary identification documents and the prevalence of document fraud in Somalia. The RPD also took account of the Kenyan identity used by the Appellant to obtain a passport and to submit an application for a study permit, all of which the Appellant alleges are fraudulent.

unredacted: The Appellant argues that the secondary identification documents were credible and convincing and, with the testimony of the Appellant and his witness, established his national and clan identity.
redacted: The Appellant argues that the secondary identification documents were credible and convincing and, with the testimony of the Appellant and his witness, established his national and clan identity.

unredacted: Following my review of the record, the transcript of the RPD hearing, the submissions of the Appellant, the documentary evidence and submissions of the Minister, and the reply affidavit and submissions of the Appellant, I find that the RPD did not err and that the Appellant did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, his personal identity and his identity as a citizen of Somalia.
redacted: Following my review of the record, the transcript of the RPD hearing, the submissions of the Appellant, the documentary evidence and submissions of the Minister, and the reply affidavit and submissions of the Appellant, I find that the RPD did not err and that the Appellant did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, his personal identity and his identity as a citizen of Somalia.

unredacted: Difficulty obtaining documentation from Somalia
redacted: Difficulty obtaining documentation from Somalia

unredacted: The objective evidence is clear:
redacted: The objective evidence is clear:

unredacted: Somalia has not had a functioning state government since 1991, and large parts of the territory are under no actual central administration or governing. This means that Somalia’s inhabitants have been unable to obtain official documents such as ID cards, passports or various certificates for the past 17 years.
redacted: Somalia has not had a functioning state government since 1991, and large parts of the territory are under no actual central administration or governing. This means that Somalia’s inhabitants have been unable to obtain official documents such as ID cards, passports or various certificates for the past 17 years.

unredacted: Witness
redacted: Witness

unredacted: The witness gave affidavit and testamentary evidence that she first met the Appellant in May 2015 and she saw him regularly until June 2016 when purchasing vegetables in a market in Kismayo, Somalia. She reconnected with him in Nairobi, Kenya in July 2017 when she went to a birthday party for a mutual friend. She gave him her brother’s telephone number so he could contact her in Canada and reconnected with him through her brother in August 2019.
redacted: The witness gave affidavit and testamentary evidence that she first met the Appellant in May 2015 and she saw him regularly until June 2016 when purchasing vegetables in a market in Kismayo, Somalia. She reconnected with him in Nairobi, Kenya in July 2017 when she went to a birthday party for a mutual friend. She gave him her brother’s telephone number so he could contact her in Canada and reconnected with him through her brother in August 2019.

unredacted: The witness gave the following evidence about the Appellant’s Somali nationality:
redacted: The witness gave the following evidence about the Appellant’s Somali nationality:

unredacted: The RPD found that while the evidence of a friend or relative can substitute for the lack of identity documents, the evidence offered by the witness is insufficient to establish the identity of the Appellant. The RPD cited the following reasons: the witness had no prior knowledge of the Appellant before meeting him in May 2015—they are not related and were strangers; the fact of their meeting in Somalia during the period May 2015 – June 2016 does not establish that the Appellant is a citizen of Somalia; and the witness did not testify about her knowledge of the status of the Appellant.
redacted: The RPD found that while the evidence of a friend or relative can substitute for the lack of identity documents, the evidence offered by the witness is insufficient to establish the identity of the Appellant. The RPD cited the following reasons: the witness had no prior knowledge of the Appellant before meeting him in May 2015—they are not related and were strangers; the fact of their meeting in Somalia during the period May 2015 – June 2016 does not establish that the Appellant is a citizen of Somalia; and the witness did not testify about her knowledge of the status of the Appellant.

unredacted: The Appellant submits that the testimony of the Appellant and the witness was consistent and establishes the Somali identity of the Appellant. I do not agree.
redacted: The Appellant submits that the testimony of the Appellant and the witness was consistent and establishes the Somali identity of the Appellant. I do not agree.

unredacted: Following my own review, I noted that there were inconsistencies between the witness’s and the Appellant’s evidence about their interactions in Kismayo and Nairobi and their reconnection in Canada:
redacted: Following my own review, I noted that there were inconsistencies between the witness’s and the Appellant’s evidence about their interactions in Kismayo and Nairobi and their reconnection in Canada:

unredacted: As these inconsistencies were not put to either the Appellant or the witness, they are not determinative, but they do support the finding of the RPD. I agree with the RPD that the relationship described between the witness and the Appellant and her lack of any basis for independently confirming his Somali nationality beyond seeing him in Kismayo from May 2015 – June 2016 is not sufficient to establish his identity.
redacted: As these inconsistencies were not put to either the Appellant or the witness, they are not determinative, but they do support the finding of the RPD. I agree with the RPD that the relationship described between the witness and the Appellant and her lack of any basis for independently confirming his Somali nationality beyond seeing him in Kismayo from May 2015 – June 2016 is not sufficient to establish his identity.

unredacted: Somalian Embassy
redacted: XXXX XXXX

unredacted: The letter from the Somalian Embassy outlines its assessment process as follows:
redacted: The letter from the Somalian Embassy outlines its assessment process as follows:

unredacted: The assessment process consists of the administration of a Community Verification Assessment (CVA) which is written in the Somali language script, as well as an oral interview in the Somali language with the settlement counselor. Both exams are based on information about Somalia including its geography, history, heritage, sociopolitical and the current political situation, the individual’s clan lineage and culture. The exams are subsequently assessed by a professional Somali settlement counselor who determines whether the individual’s identity has been sufficiently established.
redacted: The assessment process consists of the administration of a Community Verification Assessment (CVA) which is written in the Somali language script, as well as an oral interview in the Somali language with the settlement counselor. Both exams are based on information about Somalia including its geography, history, heritage, sociopolitical and the current political situation, the individual’s clan lineage and culture. The exams are subsequently assessed by a professional Somali settlement counselor who determines whether the individual’s identity has been sufficiently established.

unredacted: After reviewing the examination results of the Appellant, the Somalian Embassy confirmed that he is a national of Somalia:
redacted: After reviewing the examination results of the Appellant, the Somalian Embassy confirmed that he is a national of Somalia:

unredacted: The Somalian Embassy can thus confirm that after reviewing the outcome of the examination results of MR Omar Elmi Dihoud DOB (April 19 th 1985) UCI 4570 that this claimant is a national of Somalia, that he belongs to minority Dir sub-clan Hawiye from the Somali clan structure.
redacted: The Somalian Embassy can thus confirm that after reviewing the outcome of the examination results of MR Omar Elmi Dihoud DOB (April 19 th 1985) UCI 4570 that this claimant is a national of Somalia, that he belongs to minority Dir sub-clan Hawiye from the Somali clan structure.

unredacted: The RPD gave minimal weight to the letter from the Somalian Embassy in establishing the identity of the Appellant. The RPD found that the ability to speak Somali does not in itself establish nationality and does not establish personal identity, nor does knowledge of the geography and the culture and customs, as information regarding regions, landmarks, and other information regarding Somalia is easily accessible on the internet.
redacted: The RPD gave minimal weight to the letter from the Somalian Embassy in establishing the identity of the Appellant. The RPD found that the ability to speak Somali does not in itself establish nationality and does not establish personal identity, nor does knowledge of the geography and the culture and customs, as information regarding regions, landmarks, and other information regarding Somalia is easily accessible on the internet.

unredacted: The RPD also found that there was nothing in the Somalian Embassy letter to suggest that the information provided by the Appellant could only be provided by a citizen of Somalia or which would tip the balance in favour of establishing his identity as a citizen of Somalia, and the letter did not indicate how personal details such as the Appellant's name and date of birth were determined.
redacted: The RPD also found that there was nothing in the Somalian Embassy letter to suggest that the information provided by the Appellant could only be provided by a citizen of Somalia or which would tip the balance in favour of establishing his identity as a citizen of Somalia, and the letter did not indicate how personal details such as the Appellant's name and date of birth were determined.

unredacted: Following my own review of the Somalian Embassy letter, I noted two inconsistencies between the letter and the Appellant’s BOC. First the Somalian Embassy misnamed the Appellant as Omar Elimi Dihoud instead of the name he listed in his BOC: Omar Elmi Dihoud. Secondly the Somalian Embassy said the Appellant belongs to the minority Dir sub-clan Hawiye from the Somali clan structure, whereas the Appellant identified his nationality, ethnic and racial group or tribe as Dir sub-clan Issa in his BOC. As these inconsistencies were not put to the Appellant, they are not determinative.
redacted: Following my own review of the Somalian Embassy letter, I noted two inconsistencies between the letter and the Appellant’s BOC. First the Somalian Embassy misnamed the Appellant as Omar Elimi Dihoud instead of the name he listed in his BOC: Omar Elmi Dihoud. Secondly the Somalian Embassy said the Appellant belongs to the minority Dir sub-clan Hawiye from the Somali clan structure, whereas the Appellant identified his nationality, ethnic and racial group or tribe as Dir sub-clan Issa in his BOC. As these inconsistencies were not put to the Appellant, they are not determinative.

unredacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD erred in giving the letter from the Somalian Embassy minimum weight. The RPD did not take into consideration that the Appellant was provided an oral and written examination and just assumed that he could have memorized these details. The Appellant argues that there is nothing on the record to suggest that the Appellant would have memorized information about Somalia, or that he did do so, and that to assume this is wrong and suggests that the RPD was not impartial.
redacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD erred in giving the letter from the Somalian Embassy minimum weight. The RPD did not take into consideration that the Appellant was provided an oral and written examination and just assumed that he could have memorized these details. The Appellant argues that there is nothing on the record to suggest that the Appellant would have memorized information about Somalia, or that he did do so, and that to assume this is wrong and suggests that the RPD was not impartial.

unredacted: The Federal Court has found that a letter from the Somalian Embassy is not tendered to prove personal identity but rather as proof of Somali nationality and must be considered whether it supports the Appellant’s identity as a Somali national. “This is particularly so in cases dealing with refugee claimants from countries where identity documents are often problematic and may not be readily available, or available at all.”
redacted: The Federal Court has found that a letter from the Somalian Embassy is not tendered to prove personal identity but rather as proof of Somali nationality and must be considered whether it supports the Appellant’s identity as a Somali national. “This is particularly so in cases dealing with refugee claimants from countries where identity documents are often problematic and may not be readily available, or available at all.”

unredacted: I find that while the letter from the Somalian Embassy independently supports the Appellant’s claim to Somali nationality, it was not determinative as it could not overcome the credibility issues raised by the Appellant’s testimony, including his clan identity, the problems with the authenticity and content of the other supporting documents and the insufficient basis for the evidence of his witness.
redacted: I find that while the letter from the Somalian Embassy independently supports the Appellant’s claim to Somali nationality, it was not determinative as it could not overcome the credibility issues raised by the Appellant’s testimony, including his clan identity, the problems with the authenticity and content of the other supporting documents and the insufficient basis for the evidence of his witness.

unredacted: According to the objective evidence, 6.2% or over 3 million of Kenya’s population of approximately 48.4 million are ethnic Somalis and it shelters more than 300,000 Somali refugees as of April 2017. The Minister submitted a media article suggesting that the 2019 national statistics showing 2.7 million Kenyan Somalis is a gross underestimate.
redacted: According to the objective evidence, 6.2% or over 3 million of Kenya’s population of approximately 48.4 million are ethnic Somalis and it shelters more than 300,000 Somali refugees as of April 2017. The Minister submitted a media article suggesting that the 2019 national statistics showing 2.7 million Kenyan Somalis is a gross underestimate.

unredacted: The RPD referenced objective evidence that the shilling is the currency used in Somalia. The RPD found that the Appellant would know the currency used in Somalia if the only form of payment he received was cash, which undermined his credibility. The RPD concluded that it was unlikely that the Appellant worked at the club in Kismayo, which brings into question if he lived in Somalia.
redacted: The RPD referenced objective evidence that the shilling is the currency used in Somalia. The RPD found that the Appellant would know the currency used in Somalia if the only form of payment he received was cash, which undermined his credibility. The RPD concluded that it was unlikely that the Appellant worked at the club in Kismayo, which brings into question if he lived in Somalia.

unredacted: The Appellant argues that in Somalia they call the money “Somali lacag" (direct tanslation: Somali money), which is what the Appellant testified to at the hearing. The Appellant argues that the RPD did not ask the Appellant what the currency was in Somalia and, if asked, the Appellant would have said it was the shilling. “Civilians in Somalia simply refer to money as ‘Somali money’ they don't specify the currency. The interpreter also directly interpreted what the Appellant stated, so it was interpreted as Somali money. The Appellant submits that according to the dictionary, ‘lacag’ means money, currency, cash. Hence, the Appellant's testimony was not wrong.” The Appellant does not reference any objective evidence to support his argument.
redacted: The Appellant argues that in Somalia they call the money “Somali lacag" (direct tanslation: Somali money), which is what the Appellant testified to at the hearing. The Appellant argues that the RPD did not ask the Appellant what the currency was in Somalia and, if asked, the Appellant would have said it was the shilling. “Civilians in Somalia simply refer to money as ‘Somali money’ they don't specify the currency. The interpreter also directly interpreted what the Appellant stated, so it was interpreted as Somali money. The Appellant submits that according to the dictionary, ‘lacag’ means money, currency, cash. Hence, the Appellant's testimony was not wrong.” The Appellant does not reference any objective evidence to support his argument.

unredacted: I have reviewed both the transcript and the audio recording of the hearing. The RPD clearly asked him to identify the Somali money he was given and specifically asked what it was called. Following my review of the audio recording, I find that the Appellant answered the question differently when he replied “Somali dollar” than when he replied “Somali money.” It is also clear from both the recording and the transcript that the interpretation of the answers was different.
redacted: I have reviewed both the transcript and the audio recording of the hearing. The RPD clearly asked him to identify the Somali money he was given and specifically asked what it was called. Following my review of the audio recording, I find that the Appellant answered the question differently when he replied “Somali dollar” than when he replied “Somali money.” It is also clear from both the recording and the transcript that the interpretation of the answers was different.

unredacted: I find that the RPD did not err when it found that the Appellant did not correctly identify the currency of Somalia and that this undermined the credibility of his claim that he worked in a market and lived in Somalia.
redacted: I find that the RPD did not err when it found that the Appellant did not correctly identify the currency of Somalia and that this undermined the credibility of his claim that he worked in a market and lived in Somalia.

unredacted: When the Appellant’s counsel asked him about the location of his clan in Somalia, the Appellant replied, “Adal.” His counsel asked if his clan could be found in other parts of Somalia, to which he replied, “…there are a few in many other areas [b]ut most of them are in Mogadishu city.” Appellant’s counsel also asked if there were any in Kismayo and the Appellant replied no and that he did not meet any members of his clan in Kismayo.
redacted: When the Appellant’s counsel asked him about the location of his clan in Somalia, the Appellant replied, “Adal.” His counsel asked if his clan could be found in other parts of Somalia, to which he replied, “…there are a few in many other areas [b]ut most of them are in Mogadishu city.” Appellant’s counsel also asked if there were any in Kismayo and the Appellant replied no and that he did not meet any members of his clan in Kismayo.

unredacted: The RPD cited objective evidence that the Dir clan are scattered in small villages in the southeastearn region of Somalia and Kismayo; that the Somali clan system shapes the social, political and economic life; and that clan affiliation is the main identity factor within the Somali nation.
redacted: The RPD cited objective evidence that the Dir clan are scattered in small villages in the southeastearn region of Somalia and Kismayo; that the Somali clan system shapes the social, political and economic life; and that clan affiliation is the main identity factor within the Somali nation.

unredacted: Given the importance of clan affiliation in Somalia, the RPD made a negative credibility finding because the Appellant could not provide more details about his own clan and that he did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, that he is a member of the Dir clan.
redacted: Given the importance of clan affiliation in Somalia, the RPD made a negative credibility finding because the Appellant could not provide more details about his own clan and that he did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, that he is a member of the Dir clan.

unredacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD did not take into account that clan lineage is patrilineal and because the Appellant’s father died when he was young, he did not learn about his claim, nor did it take into account that the Appellant left Somalia when he was only 18 years old. The Appellant also argues that the RPD did not take into account an affidavit from his co-worker Abshir Ibrahim Masood in Kenya confirming the Appellant’s identity and clan identity.
redacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD did not take into account that clan lineage is patrilineal and because the Appellant’s father died when he was young, he did not learn about his claim, nor did it take into account that the Appellant left Somalia when he was only 18 years old. The Appellant also argues that the RPD did not take into account an affidavit from his co-worker Abshir Ibrahim Masood in Kenya confirming the Appellant’s identity and clan identity.

unredacted: While the Somalian Embassy letter does confirm the Appellant’s clan membership it does not detail how it reached its conclusion. I find that the Somalian Embassy confirmation of the Appellant’s clan membership does not carry much weight in light of the Appellant’s very limited knowledge about his clan. I note that the evidence from his co-worker about the Appellant’s clan membership is based on “what my mother narrated to me” without any explanation as to why his mother would be a reliable source of information.
redacted: While the Somalian Embassy letter does confirm the Appellant’s clan membership it does not detail how it reached its conclusion. I find that the Somalian Embassy confirmation of the Appellant’s clan membership does not carry much weight in light of the Appellant’s very limited knowledge about his clan. I note that the evidence from his co-worker about the Appellant’s clan membership is based on “what my mother narrated to me” without any explanation as to why his mother would be a reliable source of information.

unredacted: I have considered the Appellant’s arguments but given his sparse testimony reflecting little knowledge of his clan, that he did not connect with clan members in Kismayo and the objective evidence about the importance of clan identity in Somalia, I agree with the RPD that the Appellant did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, that he is a member of the Dir clan.
redacted: I have considered the Appellant’s arguments but given his sparse testimony reflecting little knowledge of his clan, that he did not connect with clan members in Kismayo and the objective evidence about the importance of clan identity in Somalia, I agree with the RPD that the Appellant did not establish, on a balance of probabilities, that he is a member of the Dir clan.

unredacted: Supporting documents
redacted: Supporting documents

unredacted: The RPD addressed each of the corroborative documents presented by the Appellant. The RPD found that the affidavit from the Appellant’s co-worker and the letter from his mother and a person who hosted him in 2011 did not establish the Appellant’s identity. Given the availability of fraudulent documents in Somalia and the Appellant’s admitted use of a fraudulent passport and study permit application, the RPD was not persuaded by the credibility of the supporting documents.
redacted: The RPD addressed each of the corroborative documents presented by the Appellant. The RPD found that the affidavit from the Appellant’s co-worker and the letter from his mother and a person who hosted him in 2011 did not establish the Appellant’s identity. Given the availability of fraudulent documents in Somalia and the Appellant’s admitted use of a fraudulent passport and study permit application, the RPD was not persuaded by the credibility of the supporting documents.

unredacted: I note that this finding is bolstered by Minister’s evidence that the Appellant failed to present to the RPD a primary identity document in his possession, a Kenyan driving licence, and the Appellant’s admission that he “did not submit this document to the RPD because it is an improperly obtained document which does not establish [his] identity.”
redacted: I note that this finding is bolstered by Minister’s evidence that the Appellant failed to present to the RPD a primary identity document in his possession, a Kenyan driving licence, and the Appellant’s admission that he “did not submit this document to the RPD because it is an improperly obtained document which does not establish [his] identity.”

unredacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD is suggesting that the supporting documents are fraudulent but there is nothing on the face of the documents to suggest that they are fraudulent. I disagree. I have undertaken my own review and note credibility issues on the face of the documents.
redacted: The Appellant argues that the RPD is suggesting that the supporting documents are fraudulent but there is nothing on the face of the documents to suggest that they are fraudulent. I disagree. I have undertaken my own review and note credibility issues on the face of the documents.

unredacted: The co-worker contradicts his evidence in the first paragraph of his affidavit where he states that he is a Kenyan citizen and that his status is that of a permanent resident. There are no dates referenced in the affidavit, and his unnamed mother is identified as the source of much of his information. I agree with the RPD that the co-worker’s affidavit does not credibly establish the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.
redacted: The co-worker contradicts his evidence in the first paragraph of his affidavit where he states that he is a Kenyan citizen and that his status is that of a permanent resident. There are no dates referenced in the affidavit, and his unnamed mother is identified as the source of much of his information. I agree with the RPD that the co-worker’s affidavit does not credibly establish the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.

unredacted: The credibility of affidavit of the Appellant’s mother is adversely affected by the inconsistent evidence on the record about her name:
redacted: The credibility of affidavit of the Appellant’s mother is adversely affected by the inconsistent evidence on the record about her name:

unredacted: As the Appellant’s mother did not provide any confirmation of her identity, I find, on a balance of probabilities, that her letter is not authentic and cannot, therefore, credibly establish the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.
redacted: As the Appellant’s mother did not provide any confirmation of her identity, I find, on a balance of probabilities, that her letter is not authentic and cannot, therefore, credibly establish the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.

unredacted: There is insufficient information in the letter or about the identity of the author who hosted the Appellant in 2011 to assess its credibility. On its face it does not address the determinative issues of the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.
redacted: There is insufficient information in the letter or about the identity of the author who hosted the Appellant in 2011 to assess its credibility. On its face it does not address the determinative issues of the Appellant’s identity, his Somali nationality or his clan identity.

unredacted: For all these reasons, I find that the Appellant has not met his burden to establish, on a balance of probabilities, his personal identity and his identity as a citizen of Somalia.
redacted: For all these reasons, I find that the Appellant has not met his burden to establish, on a balance of probabilities, his personal identity and his identity as a citizen of Somalia.
